reasoning: The critique targets a load-bearing part of the post’s bottom-line credence (10–40% SIE) insofar as that credence is presented as substantially driven by the assessment that ρ is likely in [-0.2, 0]. However, the post’s main claim is narrower—compute complementarity probably won’t bottleneck early—so introducing an orthogonal ‘capability wall’ doesn’t directly refute the compute-bottleneck counterargument, only the move from ‘compute not limiting’ to ‘SIE plausible at 10–40%.’ The countermodel is conceptually valid: CES/input-substitutability doesn’t by itself guarantee the existence of a path to the needed algorithmic breakthroughs, so high ρ can coexist with stalled progress. But it’s largely speculative and underspecified (no concrete reason to expect such paradigm-gating, no link to how likely it is in ML, no engagement with the post’s definition of SIE in terms of effective compute gains), so it weakens rather than seriously overturns the estimate. Claims made are mostly correct (CES doesn’t encode output ceilings; other bottlenecks can exist), and the critique is clear, focused, and contains minimal dead weight.
title: Capability walls may block SIE regardless of input substitutability
